answers.explanation:
The OCT macula demonstrated sub-foveal, focal choroidal excavation (FCE), as demonstrated by the white arrow. FCE presents clinically as subtle RPE changes on dilated fundus examination, but on macula OCT, demonstrates posterior bowing of the RPE and Bruch’s membrane complex. The outer retinal layers can fall back through the RPE (conforming FCE), as demonstrated in this image, or remain in normal position with presence of subretinal fluid (non-conforming FCE).

![](/content/media/retina-44-2.webp)

Reference

Lee CS, Woo SJ, Kim YK, Hwang DJ, Kang HM, Kim H, Lee SC. Clinical and spectral-domain optical coherence tomography findings in patients with focal choroidal excavation. Ophthalmology. 2014 May;121(5):1029-35.

answers.answerText: D. Disorganization of inner retinal layers

questions.title: Question 1
questions.text: What is the primary finding on the OCT macula above?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text: What disease process is focal choroidal excavation linked to?

answers.explanation:
First postulated in 2017 by Chung et al., FCE has been linked to pachychoroid spectrum of disease. Pachychoroid phenotype is characterized as increased choroidal thickness, dilated choroidal vessels, and breakdown of the choriocapillaris. It appears through recent literature that FCE is a manifestation of pachychoroid spectrum of disease. It is postulated that large choroidal vessels can compress the choriocapillaris, ultimately leading to ischemia and atrophy of the inner choroid and retinal pigment epithelium layer (causing FCE). 

Reference

Chung, H, Byeon SH, Freund, BK. Focal choroidal excavation and its association with pachychoroid spectrum disorders. Retina 2017;37(2):199-221.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text:
Three weeks later, the patient presented with worsening vision OS. A repeat OCT macula was performed and demonstrated below.

![](/content/media/retina-44-3.webp)

To better characterize the hyper-reflective foci at the FCE, an OCT-angiography was conducted. The outer retina/choriocapillaris segment with accompanying flow B-scan is shown below.

![](/content/media/retina-44-4.webp)

What is the key finding in the above OCTA?

answers.answerText: B. Disorganization of inner retinal layers

answers.explanation:
The flow B-scan demonstrates new blood flow at the level of the RPE within the choroidal excavation, and when correlated to the ORCC segment of the OCTA, most likely demonstrates a new CNVM. Choroidal neovascularization has been shown to be a complication of conforming FCE, but it also may be a cause of the FCE as part of the pachychoroid spectrum. Due to the temporal aspect of this patient presentation, it can be concluded that the FCE led to CNVM, causing vision loss. The image below shows the initial OCTA flow B-scan on initial presentation (left) and the 3-week OCTA on the right, demonstrating serial progression of blood flow on flow B-scan images.

![](/content/media/retina-44-5.webp)

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text: What is the current treatment for CNVM secondary to FCE?

answers.explanation: Though all 3 of PDT, anti-VEGF injections and observation have been shown in literature to demonstrate efficacy in the management of FCE, when a CNVM is present, anti-VEGF injections are the first-line treatment.

description: 23F presenting for a 3-month history of worsening vision OS
patientPresentation:
